statements.text: On October 15, 2009, Richard and Mayumi Heene released a homemade helium balloon over Fort Collins, Colorado, claiming their six-year-old son Falcon was trapped inside.
The saucer-shaped balloon, built by the Heenes as an experiment, reached about 7,000 feet during a 90-minute flight before landing near Denver International Airport.
Authorities including the National Guard and local police pursued the balloon, but Falcon was later found hiding in the family’s attic.
Public suspicion of a hoax arose after Falcon said on CNN’s Larry King Live, 'You guys said we did this for the show,' suggesting the event was staged.
Larimer County Sheriff Jim Alderden later declared the incident a publicity stunt designed to attract attention for a potential reality TV show.
Richard Heene pleaded guilty to attempting to influence a public servant, receiving 90 days in jail, while Mayumi Heene received 20 days of weekend jail and both were ordered to pay restitution.
The Heenes claimed they accepted the plea deal under threat of Mayumi’s deportation and have since maintained their innocence.
Colorado Governor Jared Polis pardoned the Heenes in December 2020, citing that they had already paid their public debt and deserved a second chance.
Before the hoax, the Heene family had appeared twice on the reality show 'Wife Swap' and had unsuccessfully pitched multiple TV concepts including a science-themed series.
Richard Heene was known as a storm chaser and self-promoter, involving his children in storm expeditions and UFO-hunting activities.
The balloon, made of plastic tarps and aluminum foil, could lift only about 65 pounds, making it unlikely to have carried a child.
Investigators found that the family planned the hoax about two weeks in advance and instructed their children to lie to authorities and media.
The event generated massive global media coverage, internet memes, and parodies as the 'Balloon Boy' story dominated online searches.
Critics accused the media of sensationalism and poor verification, while scholars noted the incident blurred lines between reality television and journalism.
In 2011, Richard Heene auctioned the balloon for charity, donating proceeds to victims of the 2011 Tōhoku earthquake and tsunami.
The hoax was later chronicled in documentaries including the 2019 ABC News interview and the 2025 Netflix film 'Trainwreck: Balloon Boy' directed by Gillian Pachter.
